abstract.shortdesc: The rule-statement presents the individual rules associated with an element.

rule.rule-statement: Write rules as direct orders: start with a verb followed by a complement.
rule.justification: Rules ensure that users take the correct actions. If they must do something, just tell them to do it.

examplefig.codeblock: <rule-statement><action>Include the instruction sheet in every shipment</action>.</rule-statement>

rule.rule-statement: If a rule applies only under specific conditions, state the conditions first.
rule.justification: Some users take actions as they read. They may read the conditions after they have performed the action.

examplefig.codeblock: <rule-statement><action>Add 1 cup of water</action>, <if-condition>if the indicator is in the yellow zone</if-condition>.</rule-statement>
<rule-statement><if-condition>If there is less than 1 meter of snow</if-condition>, <action>turn off the heavy snow settings</action>.</rule-statement>

rule.rule-statement: When actions must not be taken, start the action part of the rule with a negative.

examplefig.codeblock: <rule-statement><if-condition>If the indicator is red</if-condition>, <action>do not drink the water</action>.</rule-statement>
